newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: Pay talks deadlocked at Grindrod.
newsitem.headline: Pay talks deadlocked at Grindrod.

text.p: Pay talks with three divisions of striking workers at South African freight firm Grindrod (Pty) Ltd are deadlocked, but services are continuing, a company spokeswoman said on Monday.
The company has offered to raise wages by 8.5 percent, but the South African Freight and Dock Workers' Union has demanded 13 percent across the board, Grindrod's Margaret Rowe said.
"Services are still continuing, we have mustered everybody to help," Rowe told Reuters, adding only Durban workers were striking.
"The group has taken the decision not to make any further moves on its offer of an across the board increase of 8.5 percent," Rowe said in a statement.
Striking workers have been locked out to ensure continuation of services, Rowe said, but could not immediately say how many workers were affected.
The union could not immediately be reached for comment.
The three divisions are Grindrod International Freight, Mitchell Cotts Maritime and King and Sons -- all shipping agents.
Another issue was the table of minimum rates of pay, Rowe said. One division had settled, and the company was awaiting union response on the new rates formulated for the other two divisions.
